name: Mount Lafayette

trails_config.name: Franconia Ridge Loop
trails_config.description: One of New England's most spectacular hikes. Ascend via Falling Waters Trail past beautiful cascades, traverse the exposed Franconia Ridge with stunning 360° views, and descend via Old Bridle Path past Greenleaf Hut.

trails_config.name: Old Bridle Path
trails_config.description: Historic route to Lafayette via Greenleaf Hut. Less steep than Falling Waters but longer. Great views from AMC's Greenleaf Hut.

trails_config.name: Falling Waters Trail
trails_config.description: Steep but rewarding route passing three beautiful waterfalls. Connects to Franconia Ridge at Little Haystack Mountain.

trails_config.name: Greenleaf Trail
trails_config.description: Most direct route from Cannon Mountain Tramway parking. Passes through Greenleaf Hut. Less crowded alternative to Lafayette Place routes.

trails_config.name: Skookumchuck Trail
trails_config.description: Longer but quieter approach from the north. Excellent solitude compared to Lafayette Place routes. Intersects Garfield Ridge Trail.

seo.meta_title: Franconia Ridge Loop: Trail Conditions, Maps & Parking 2026
seo.meta_description: Plan your Mount Lafayette hike with live conditions, 5 trail maps & parking info. NH 4000-Footer at 5,260 ft.

schema_place.name: Mount Lafayette
schema_place.description: Mount Lafayette is a 5,260 foot peak in New Hampshire offering hiking trails with scenic views.

mainEntity.name: How long does it take to hike Mount Lafayette?

acceptedAnswer.text: Most routes on Mount Lafayette take 4-6 hours round trip. The most popular trail is 8.9 miles with Hard difficulty. Start early, especially on weekends when parking fills quickly.

mainEntity.name: Is Mount Lafayette hard to hike?

acceptedAnswer.text: Mount Lafayette is rated Hard. At 5,260 feet, expect challenging terrain above treeline with potential for rapid weather changes. Proper footwear and preparation are essential.

mainEntity.name: Do I need a permit to hike Mount Lafayette?

acceptedAnswer.text: No hiking permit is required for Mount Lafayette. However, parking fees may apply at trailheads (typically $3-5/day for WMNF or state parks). A WMNF parking pass covers most White Mountain trailheads.

mainEntity.name: What is the best trail to hike Mount Lafayette?

acceptedAnswer.text: The most popular route is the Franconia Ridge Loop, offering One of New England's most spectacular hikes. Ascend via Falling Waters Trail past beautiful cascades, traverse the exposed Franconia Ridge with stunni.

mainEntity.name: When is the best time to hike Mount Lafayette?

acceptedAnswer.text: The best hiking season for Mount Lafayette is late May through October. Summer and fall offer the best conditions, though expect crowds on weekends. Winter hiking requires specialized gear and experience.

page_content.description:
At 5,260 feet, Mount Lafayette ranks among New Hampshire's celebrated 4000-Footers—a collection of 48 peaks that challenge and inspire hikers throughout the Northeast. This hard summit offers a quintessential White Mountain experience.

Popular Routes

The most popular route, **Franconia Ridge Loop**, covers 8.9 miles and is rated Hard. One of New England's most spectacular hikes. Ascend via Falling Waters Trail past beautiful cascades, traverse the exposed Franconia Ridge with stunning 360° views, and descend via Old Bridle Path pas

Peak Bagging

**Extend Your Adventure:** Mount Lincoln lies just 0.9 miles away, making it an excellent addition for ambitious hikers looking to bag multiple summits.

spring.title: Spring Conditions
spring.conditions: Muddy trails, snow above 3000ft until May
spring.tips: Trail closures for mud season (April-May). Check conditions before heading out.

summer.title: Summer Conditions
summer.tips: Start early to avoid afternoon storms and parking issues. Peak crowds on weekends.

fall.title: Fall Conditions
fall.conditions: Peak foliage late Sept, early snow possible in October
fall.tips: Peak foliage brings peak crowds. Weekday hikes recommended. Watch for ice above treeline in late October.

winter.title: Winter Conditions
winter.conditions: Full winter conditions, extreme cold and wind above treeline
winter.tips: Winter hiking requires specialized skills and gear. Never hike alone. Check avalanche conditions for steeper terrain.

current_hazards: ⚠️ ALPINE ZONE: Weather changes rapidly. Turn back if conditions deteriorate.
Winter conditions in effect - full mountaineering gear required
Hypothermia risk - temperatures 20-40°F colder at summit
Trail markers may be buried under snow
